trial_identification.studytitle: Diet and weight loss in men
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effect of a high protein low carbohydrate compared to a high carbohydrate diet moderate protein diet on weight loss and wellbeing in obese men

interventions.interventions: Participants assigned to a high protein (35% of energy) for 12 months.
interventions.comparator: Participants assigned to high carbohydrate diet (58% of energy) for 12 months.

primaryOutcome.timepoint: At 12 and 52 weeks after start of diet intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: FMD, lipids, insulin glucose CRP, blood pressure folate, homocysteine body composition.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At 12 and 52 weeks after start of diet intervention.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Have at least one CVD risk factor other than obesityBMI 27-40kg/m2
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Use of any form of drug therapy or medication or supplements on a regular basis that may interfere with bowel function (e.g. laxatives, antibiotics, anti-diarrhoeals or probiotics)Consumption of any over-the-counter medication that in the opinion of the investigator could interfere with the study.History or presence of gastrointestinal, renal or hepatic disease of any cause.

trial_design.sequence: Random allocation using computer software Clinstat

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The replacement of dietary carbohydrate with protein, combined with a low intake of fat, has been shown to induce larger weight loss in overweight participants when compared with conventional high carbohydrate/low fat diets and is an increasingly popular method for weight loss among the general public, suggesting this is a favourable weight loss regime for overweight people. There are concerns over the safety of the use of high protein-red meat diets, as red meat, although controversial, is proposed to increase the risk of colon cancer. Although a high protein-red meat diet may be associated with increasing the risk of colon cancer due to the higher content of meat, such a diet is also associated with weight loss and improved insulin sensitivity, which reduce colon cancer risk. From this it can be suggested that a higher protein dietary pattern used for weight loss that remains low in fat and high in fibre rich foods, in association with moderate exercise may not increase the risk of colon cancer. The impact of long term use of high protein-red meat diets on colon cancer risk has not been assessed. This study will assess the safety of high protein-red meat diets as a method for weight loss in overweight participants. It will also investigate a series of secondary outcomes that impact on total health status.
